description: This self-guided cycle itinerary has been created by the Open House team to explore exterior architecture in Richmond.

factsheet.heading: Route and description
paragraphs: RICHMOND CYCLE ROUTES
Richmond cycle route 1 Hampton Court and Twickenham 16 km 55 mins

Start at: Hampton Court Palace KT8 9AU
Garrick’s Temple to Shakespeare
Bushy House
Langdon Down Centre
The Boathouse Design Studio
Strawberry Hill House
Pope’s Grotto
York House
Orleans House Gallery
Marble Hill House
Turner’s House
The Boat and the Pavilion
Kilmorey Mausoleum
Clifton Lodge TW1 1QN

Hampton Court Palace KT8 9AU
Magnificent palace and grounds with outstanding work of 16th, 17th and 18th centuries

Directions:
At the roundabout in front of the palace turn northwest onto Hampton Court Rd/A308 1.5km > Turn left on Garrick’s Lawn and the Temple will be ahead of you

Garrick’s Temple to Shakespeare The Stock Yard/Hampton Ct Rd, Hampton TW12 2EJ
Grade I listed Georgian garden building. Tribute to Shakespeare built in the Ionic style by actor David Garrick. Arcadian Thames-side setting in restored 18C gardens thought to be by Capability Brown.

Directions; 
Return to Hampton Court Rd and turn right 25m > Turn left into Bushy Park 1.04 km > At the Diana Fountain turn left onto Chestnut Avenue 750m > Turn left onto Cobbler's Walk 105 m > Slight right onto Glazebrook Rd 395 m > Turn left onto Bushy Rd 47m > Bushy House is on your left

Bushy House Bushy Rd, Teddington TW11 0EB
Original house was built for Edward Proger. From 1797 the residence of William, Duke of Clarence (later William IV) and his mistress Dora Jordan. Now part of the National Physical Laboratory (NPL).

Directions:
Return down Glazebrook Rd 395 m > Continue onto Cobbler's Walk 1.5km, crossing Chestnut Avenue > Turn left onto Sandy Ln/B358 51 m > Turn right onto Vicarage Rd 353 m > Turn left onto Upper Teddington Rd/A310 531 m > Turn right onto Langdon Park (Restricted usage road) 200m > The Centre is ahead of you

Langdon Down Centre 6 Langdon Park, Teddington TW11 9PS
Grade II* listed Normansfield Theatre and Langdon Down Museum of Learning Disability. Gothic proscenium arch and elaborate stage and scenery. Built as part of the Normansfield Hospital for patients/students with learning disabilities.

Directions:
Turn left onto Kingston Rd/A310 157 m > Turn left onto Normansfield Ave 387 m > Turn left onto Broom Rd 1.52 km > Turn left onto Ferry Rd 38 m > The Design Studio is on your right

The Boathouse Design Studio 3 Ferry Rd, Teddington TW11 9NN
Originally built to house the Royal Barge in 1862 and then used for boat building for three generations, The Boathouse is now office space for the creative industries.

Directions:
Head southwest on Ferry Rd 34 m > Turn right onto Manor Rd/A310 > Continue to follow A310 1.36 km > At the roundabout, take the 1st exit onto Waldegrave Rd/A309 106 m > Turn left 33 m > Turn left 26 m to reach Strawberry Hill House

Strawberry Hill House 270 Waldegrave Rd, Twickenham TW1 4ST
Influential early Gothic revival building restored to its dramatic original glory, recreating Horace Walpole's original intention for his own home.

Directions: 
Turn right onto Waldegrave Rd/A309 98 m > At the roundabout, take the 1st exit onto Cross Deep/A310 300 m > Pope’s Grotto is on your right (in Radnor House School)

Pope’s Grotto, Cross Deep, Twickenham, London TW1 4QG 
Grotto with mineral decoration is the last remaining part of Alexander Pope's villa built in 1720. The villa was demolished 1808 and replaced and redeveloped many times in following years but Pope's Grotto remains.

Directions: 
Continue north on Cross Deep/A310 643 m > Turn right onto King St/A305/A310 158 m > Turn right onto Water Ln 12 m > Turn left onto Church St 233 m > Turn right onto Hall Rd 52 m > York House is ahead of you

York House, Hall Rd, Twickenham TW1 3AA
York House is a Grade II listed building and is scheduled as an Ancient Monument, dating from 17C. To provide the Council with offices the ground floor has been altered to accommodate a Council Chamber, Mayor's Parlour, Committee Rooms, cloakrooms and lavatories. It was decided to use York House as the Municipal Offices when the London Borough of Richmond upon Thames council was formed in 1965.

Directions:
Head southwest on Hall Rd toward Church St 52 m > Turn left onto Church St 37 m > Turn left toward Riverside 87 m > Turn left onto Riverside 413 m > Slight left to stay on Riverside 75 m > Orleans House Gallery is on your left

Orleans House Gallery Orleans Gardens, Orleans Rd, Twickenham TW1 3DG
Louis Philippe, Duc d'Orleans, lived here between 1815-17. Gibbs's Baroque Octagon Room and adjoining gallery/19C stable block are the remaining parts of Orleans House. The Octagon Room was restored in 2018.

Directions: 
Head east on Riverside toward Orleans Rd 151 m > Turn left onto Orleans Rd 349 m > Turn right onto Chapel Rd 81 m > Turn right onto Montpelier Row 108 m > Marble Hill House is ahead of you

Marble Hill House 29 Montpelier Row, Twickenham TW1 2NQ
Marble Hill House was built between 1724 and 1729 as a summer villa for Henrietta Howard, mistress of George II and later Countess of Suffolk. It was an idyllic Thames-side retreat from court life. In this perfectly proportioned villa, inspired by the 16C architect Palladio, she entertained many of the poets and wits of the age.

Directions:
Return to Montpellier Row 100m > Turn right onto Richmond Rd/A305 50m > Turn left onto Sandycoombe Rd 233 m > Turner’s House is on your right

Turner’s House in Twickenham 43 Sandycoombe Rd, St Margarets, Twickenham TW1 2LR
Sandycombe Lodge was built in 1813 to the designs of England’s great landscape painter, J.M.W. Turner; working here as his own architect to create a quiet retreat for himself, away from the pressures of the London art world.

Directions:
Head northwest on Sandycoombe Rd 39 m > Turn left onto St. Margarets Rd/A3004 and go through 1 roundabout 632 m > Turn left onto Orchard Rd 157 m > the house is on your left

The Boat and the Pavilion 27 Orchard Rd, St Margarets, Twickenham TW1 1LX
Ground floor rear extension for a family of sailors. The open plan layout is defined by curved, floating walls (the boat) and a sculpted ceiling (the pavilion), playfully combining compressed and expanded spaces. Davide di Martino Architect of Unagru Limited 2015

Directions:
Head east on Orchard Rd 157 m > Turn left onto St. Margarets Rd/A3004 275 m > the Mausoleum is on your right opposite the Ailsa Tavern

Kilmorey Mausoleum 275 St Margaret's Road (opposite Ailsa Tavern) LondonTW1 1NJ
Egyptian-style, pink and grey mausoleum created for the second Earl of Kilmorey. The form relates to the shrines at the heart of Egyptian Temples. H.E. Kendal 1854

Directions:
From St Margarets Rd turn left onto St. Margarets Dr 92 m > Slight left to stay on St. Margarets Dr 14 m > Clifton Lodge is on your left

Clifton Lodge and the Violet Needham Chapel 10 St. Margarets Dr, Twickenham TW1 1QN
Clifton Lodge is the last remaining original feature of St Margarets House. Originally an orangery, it is now the home of Rambert School of Ballet and Contemporary Dance. The Violet Needham Chapel houses two further dance studios.

Directions: 
Continue on St Margaret’s Drive/Ranelagh Drive 300m to the Richmond Lock (Middlesex Side) > You can carry your bike across the river on the footbridge
Richmond Cycle Route 2: Richmond Petersham and Ham - 8 km, 35 minutes

Start at: Richmond and Hillcroft Adult Community College TW9 2QJ
The Old Town Hall, Richmond
Bethlehem Chapel
Lépine Residence
Grove Gardens Chapel
Richmond, the American International University in London
Finish at: Ham House and Garden TW10 7RS

Richmond Lock Building (Surrey Side), The Towpath, Richmond London TW9 2QJ
Example of good quality late Victorian functional design.

Directions: 
Head southeast on Kew Riverside Walk bike path under Twickenham Bridge and railway bridge 400m > Turn left via bike lane into Old Palace Ln 300m > Turn left onto Pembroke Villas 190 m > Slight right onto Portland Terrace 210 m > Turn left onto Little Green 180 m > Continue onto Parkshot 170 m > The College is on your left

Richmond and Hillcroft Adult Community College
A centre of excellence for adults, providing learning, training and personal development. As a beacon for adult learning, this project facilitates an accessible, effective teaching environment that is substantially more sustainable. Victorian building extended in 2015 by Morris+Company.

Directions:
Return along Parkshot 170m > Continue onto Little Green 180 m > Turn left onto Duke St 94 m > Turn left onto Duke St/The Square/A305Continue to follow The Square/A305 38 m > Turn right onto Eton St/A305/A307 141 m > Turn right onto Paradise Rd/A305/A307 > Continue to follow Red Lion St/A305/A307 285 m > Slight left onto Hill St/A307 30 m > Turn left to stay on Hill St/A307 35 m > Turn right onto Whittaker Ave 38 m > The Old Town Hall is on your left

The Old Town Hall, Richmond Old Town Hall, Whittaker Avenue Richmond TW9 1TP
Red brick and Bath stone grand 'Elizabethan Renaissance' style building altered by war, political changes and reflecting Richmond's history. Overlooking the war memorial and the Thames.

Directions:
Return to Hill St/A307 and turn right > Turn left on bike path to Castle Yard 37 m > Turn right onto Castle Yard 73 m > Continue on bike path to Ormond Rd 45 m > Turn left onto Ormond Rd 105 m > Turn left onto Church Terrace 36 m > The Bethlehem Chapel is on your left

Bethlehem Chapel 5 Church Terrace, Richmond TW10 6SE
An independent Calvinistic chapel on the east side of Church Terrace in Richmond, London. Built in 1797, the small one-storey stucco building is Grade II* listed. It still has its original galleried interior with pews and pulpit.

Directions:
Return along Church Terrace 36 m > Slight left onto The Hermitage 152 m >Turn left onto The Vineyard 94 m > Turn left onto Halford Rd 119 m > The Lépine Residence is on your left

Lépine Residence 29A Halford Rd, Richmond TW10 6AW
Comprehensive transformation of the existing Victorian terrace house into a modern dwelling. Every area of the house was intensively studied then optimized for daylight penetration, spatial flow, layout efficiency, storage integration and practical requirements. The modern design confronts the inherent restrictions of the original property, including small rooms, awkward circulation, dampness, and low internal daylight levels.

Directions: 
Return southeast on Halford Rd 119 m > Slight left onto The Vineyard 59 m > Continue onto Onslow Rd 399 m > Continue onto Marlborough Rd 254 m > Turn left onto Queen's Rd/B353 520 m > Turn right onto Lower Grove Rd 300 m > Turn left to enter the cemetery 150 m > The Chapel is on your left

Grove Gardens Chapel 5 Lower Grove Rd, Richmond TW10 6HP
A small, charming Gothic Revival cemetery chapel made from Kentish ragstone, with plate tracery and a mosaic altarpiece. It was deconsecrated and then restored for community use. Thomas Hardy was apprenticed to the architect.

Return to Lower Grove Rd and turn left 120 m > Continue on the car-free section of Lower Grove Rd 208 m > Continue onto Grove Rd 156 m > Turn left to stay on Grove Rd 47 m > 
Turn right onto Cambrian Rd 46 m > Turn left onto Queen's Rd/B353 258 m > Turn right at Stafford Pl into the University grounds 125m

Richmond, the American International University in London 144-150 Richmond Hill, Richmond TW10 6RW
An impressive neo-Gothic building set in 5 acres. Originally home of the Wesley Theological Institution and now Richmond University, built of Bath stone with façade largely unchanged. Grounds contain many rare specimens of plants and trees

Directions: Return to Queen's Rd/B353 > Turn right out of the University grounds onto Queen's Rd/B353 251 m > At the roundabout, take the 2nd exit onto Richmond Hill/B353 200m > Turn left into Nightingale Lane 240m > Turn left into Petersham Rd/A307 600m > Turn right to follow Petersham Rd 450m > Turn right at Forge Ln onto bike path 600m > Turn right on bike path 150m >Turn left 100m to Ham House main entrance

Ham House and Garden Ham House, Richmond TW10 7RS
Built in 1610, Ham House was greatly extended in the 1670s. One of a series of grand houses and palaces built along the Thames, and one of the best examples of a 17C home in England. Exquisite interiors and beautiful historic gardens. NB Not participating in Open House 2021
Richmond ride 3 Mortlake and Kew 5km

Start at: Sir Richard Burton's Mausoleum SW14 8PR
St Leonards Court Air Raid Shelter, East Sheen
Mortlake Crematorium
The National Archives
Kew House
Parish Church of St Anne
Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew TW9 3AB

Sir Richard Burton's Mausoleum - In the churchyard of St Mary Magdalen's RC Church, 61 North Worple Way, Mortlake SW14 8PR
Grade II* listed mausoleum in the form of an Arab tent with ripples in the stone imitating canvas. Interior is embellished with oriental lamps, devotional paintings and camel bells.

Directions:
Head west on N Worple Way 289 m > Turn left onto Sheen Ln/B351 179 m > Turn right onto St Leonards Rd 164 m > Turn right onto Palmers Rd 60 m > Turn left to stay on Palmers Rd 20 m > St Leonards Court is on your left

St Leonards Court Air Raid Shelter 84 St Leonards Court, Mortlake, London SW14 7LS
The Air Raid Shelter was first built in 1939 for the residents of St Leonards Court. A dormitory annex with 48 beds was added in 1940. Some of the original features, such as handmade lampshades, are remarkably well preserved.

Directions:
Return to St Leonards Rd and turn left 164 m > Turn left onto Sheen Ln/B351 350 m > Turn left onto Lower Richmond Rd/A3003 100m > Turn right onto Ship Ln 197 m > Ship Ln turns slightly left and becomes Thames Bank 221 m > Continue under Chiswick Bridge along the Thames Path 294 m > Turn left at Putney Town Rowing Club to reach Barker Close 90 m > Turn left into Kew Meadows Path into the crematorium grounds 170m

Mortlake Crematorium 2 Barker Cl, Kew, Richmond TW9 4ET
A rare and distinctive example of Art Deco design, with exceptional quality and character. Italianate style cloisters with discrete brick detailing.

Directions:
Head west on Kew Meadows Path 250m to exit the Crematorium grounds > Cross Townmead Rd at the roundabout and continue east along Kew Meadows Path (car-free) 600m > At Bessant Drive turn right and follow Bessant Drive to the destination 500m

The National Archives 8-10 Strand Dr, Kew, Richmond TW9 4DX
South West London's hidden Brutalist masterpiece. Architects: McMaster/Clavering/Miller/O'Reilly 1977

Directions:
Exit the National Archives grounds onto Ruskin Avenue 148 m > Turn right onto Mortlake Rd/A205 413 m > Turn right onto Cambridge Rd 79m > Turn left to stay on Cambridge Rd 19 m > the house is on your left

Kew House 10 Cambridge Rd, Kew TW9 3JB
A playful family home set around a courtyard and formed from two gabled Corten steel buildings. Part of Open House & evolving every year since 2014. Architects: Piercy & Co. NB Not participating in Open House 2021

Directions:
Continue north on Cambridge Rd 50 m > Turn left onto Gloucester Rd 92 m > Turn left onto Kew Green 31 m > Cross the main road (walk your bicycle) to reach the Church

Parish Church of St Anne 37 Kew Green, Kew TW9 3AB
Grade II* listed, originally built as a chapel under the patronage of Queen Anne in 1714 and subsequently enlarged. Many notable memorials including to scientist William Jackson Hooker and tombs of Thomas Gainsborough and Johan Zoffany.

Directions:
Continue along Kew Green 350m to main gate of Kew Gardens

Royal Botanic Gardens Kew Gardens, Kew Rd, Kew, Richmond TW9 3AB, UK
World famous botanical gardens and home to a range of architecturally distinguished buildings, important scientific collections and horticultural laboratories. Different aspects of this work are accessible for Open House each year.

name: Self-guided Cycle Tour of Richmond, by Open House
